Package edu.cornell.gdiac.json

Class LoadingMode

java.lang.Object
edu.cornell.gdiac.json.LoadingMode
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.ControllerListener, com.badlogic.gdx.InputProcessor, com.badlogic.gdx.Screen
public class LoadingMode extends Object implements com.badlogic.gdx.Screen, com.badlogic.gdx.InputProcessor, com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.ControllerListener
Class that provides a loading screen for the state of the game. You still DO NOT need to understand this class for this lab. We will talk about this class much later in the course. This class provides a basic template for a loading screen to be used at the start of the game or between levels. Feel free to adopt this to your needs. You will note that this mode has some textures that are not loaded by the AssetManager. You are never required to load through the AssetManager. But doing this will block the application. That is why we try to have as few resources as possible for this loading screen.

  • Constructor Details

    • LoadingMode

      public LoadingMode(String file, GameCanvas canvas)
      Creates a LoadingMode with the default budget, size and position.
      Parameters:
      file - The asset directory to load in the background
      canvas - The game canvas to draw to

    • LoadingMode

      public LoadingMode(String file, GameCanvas canvas, int millis)
      Creates a LoadingMode with the default size and position. The budget is the number of milliseconds to spend loading assets each animation frame. This allows you to do something other than load assets. An animation frame is ~16 milliseconds. So if the budget is 10, you have 6 milliseconds to do something else. This is how game companies animate their loading screens.
      Parameters:
      file - The asset directory to load in the background
      canvas - The game canvas to draw to
      millis - The loading budget in milliseconds

  • Method Details

    • getBudget

      public int getBudget()
      Returns the budget for the asset loader. The budget is the number of milliseconds to spend loading assets each animation frame. This allows you to do something other than load assets. An animation frame is ~16 milliseconds. So if the budget is 10, you have 6 milliseconds to do something else. This is how game companies animate their loading screens.
      Returns:
      the budget in milliseconds

    • setBudget

      public void setBudget(int millis)
      Sets the budget for the asset loader. The budget is the number of milliseconds to spend loading assets each animation frame. This allows you to do something other than load assets. An animation frame is ~16 milliseconds. So if the budget is 10, you have 6 milliseconds to do something else. This is how game companies animate their loading screens.
      Parameters:
      millis - the budget in milliseconds

    • isReady

      public boolean isReady()
      Returns true if all assets are loaded and the player is ready to go.
      Returns:
      true if the player is ready to go

    • getAssets

      public AssetDirectory getAssets()
      Returns the asset directory produced by this loading screen This asset loader is NOT owned by this loading scene, so it persists even after the scene is disposed. It is your responsbility to unload the assets in this directory.
      Returns:
      the asset directory produced by this loading screen

    • dispose

      public void dispose()
      Called when this screen should release all resources.
      Specified by:
      dispose in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen

    • update

      private void update(float delta)
      Update the status of this player mode. We prefer to separate update and draw from one another as separate methods, instead of using the single render() method that LibGDX does. We will talk about why we prefer this in lecture.
      Parameters:
      delta - Number of seconds since last animation frame

    • draw

      private void draw()
      Draw the status of this player mode. We prefer to separate update and draw from one another as separate methods, instead of using the single render() method that LibGDX does. We will talk about why we prefer this in lecture.

    • drawProgress

      private void drawProgress(GameCanvas canvas)
      Updates the progress bar according to loading progress The progress bar is composed of parts: two rounded caps on the end, and a rectangle in a middle. We adjust the size of the rectangle in the middle to represent the amount of progress.
      Parameters:
      canvas - The drawing context

    • render

      public void render(float delta)
      Called when the Screen should render itself. We defer to the other methods update() and draw(). However, it is VERY important that we only quit AFTER a draw.
      Specified by:
      render in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen
      Parameters:
      delta - Number of seconds since last animation frame

    • resize

      public void resize(int width, int height)
      Called when the Screen is resized. This can happen at any point during a non-paused state but will never happen before a call to show().
      Specified by:
      resize in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen
      Parameters:
      width - The new width in pixels
      height - The new height in pixels

    • pause

      public void pause()
      Called when the Screen is paused. This is usually when it's not active or visible on screen. An Application is also paused before it is destroyed.
      Specified by:
      pause in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen

    • resume

      public void resume()
      Called when the Screen is resumed from a paused state. This is usually when it regains focus.
      Specified by:
      resume in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen

    • show

      public void show()
      Called when this screen becomes the current screen for a Game.
      Specified by:
      show in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen

    • hide

      public void hide()
      Called when this screen is no longer the current screen for a Game.
      Specified by:
      hide in interface com.badlogic.gdx.Screen

    • setScreenListener

      public void setScreenListener(ScreenListener listener)
      Sets the ScreenListener for this mode The ScreenListener will respond to requests to quit.

    • touchDown

      public boolean touchDown(int screenX, int screenY, int pointer, int button)
      Called when the screen was touched or a mouse button was pressed. This method checks to see if the play button is available and if the click is in the bounds of the play button. If so, it signals the that the button has been pressed and is currently down. Any mouse button is accepted.
      Specified by:
      touchDown in interface com.badlogic.gdx.InputProcessor
      Parameters:
      screenX - the x-coordinate of the mouse on the screen
      screenY - the y-coordinate of the mouse on the screen
      pointer - the button or touch finger number
      Returns:
      whether to hand the event to other listeners.

    • touchUp

      public boolean touchUp(int screenX, int screenY, int pointer, int button)
      Called when a finger was lifted or a mouse button was released. This method checks to see if the play button is currently pressed down. If so, it signals the that the player is ready to go.
      Specified by:
      touchUp in interface com.badlogic.gdx.InputProcessor
      Parameters:
      screenX - the x-coordinate of the mouse on the screen
      screenY - the y-coordinate of the mouse on the screen
      pointer - the button or touch finger number
      Returns:
      whether to hand the event to other listeners.

    • buttonDown

      public boolean buttonDown(com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.Controller controller, int buttonCode)
      Called when a button on the Controller was pressed. The buttonCode is controller specific. This listener only supports the start button on an X-Box controller. This outcome of this method is identical to pressing (but not releasing) the play button.
      Specified by:
      buttonDown in interface com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.ControllerListener
      Parameters:
      controller - The game controller
      buttonCode - The button pressed
      Returns:
      whether to hand the event to other listeners.

    • buttonUp

      public boolean buttonUp(com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.Controller controller, int buttonCode)
      Called when a button on the Controller was released. The buttonCode is controller specific. This listener only supports the start button on an X-Box controller. This outcome of this method is identical to releasing the the play button after pressing it.
      Specified by:
      buttonUp in interface com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.ControllerListener
      Parameters:
      controller - The game controller
      buttonCode - The button pressed
      Returns:
      whether to hand the event to other listeners.

    • keyDown

      public boolean keyDown(int keycode)
      Called when a key is pressed (UNSUPPORTED)
      Specified by:
      keyDown in interface com.badlogic.gdx.InputProcessor
      Parameters:
      keycode - the key pressed
      Returns:
      whether to hand the event to other listeners.

    • axisMoved

      public boolean axisMoved(com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.Controller controller, int axisCode, float value)
      Called when an axis on the Controller moved. (UNSUPPORTED) The axisCode is controller specific. The axis value is in the range [-1, 1].
      Specified by:
      axisMoved in interface com.badlogic.gdx.controllers.ControllerListener
      Parameters:
      controller - The game controller
      axisCode - The axis moved
      value - The axis value, -1 to 1
      Returns:
      whether to hand the event to other listeners.
